Also the third moment, $E[|G_i|^3]$, is finite. To proceed further, we state the Berry Esseen's theorem (see Theorem 6.4.1 in \cite{Athr}). 
\begin{prop}[Berry Esseen's Theorem]
Let $X_i,~1\leq i\leq n$, be an i.i.d. sequence of random variables with mean $\mu$, variance $\sigma^2 <\infty$ and $E[|X_1|^3] < \infty$. Let $S_n = \sum\limits_{i=1}^n X_i$. Then we have, for any $x \in \mathbb{R}$,

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex25.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle:=E[G_{i}]=\frac{1}{2}\log\left(1+\frac{E[Y]}{\sigma^{2}}\right)," display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>:=</mo><mrow><mi>E</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mi>G</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi>E</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>Y</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow><msup><mi>σ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac></mstyle></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex26.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle V_{EG}" display="inline"><msub><mi>V</mi><mrow><mi>E</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>G</mi></mrow></msub></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex26.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle:=Var(G_{i})=\frac{E[Y]}{E[Y]+\sigma^{2}}." display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>:=</mo><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>G</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi>E</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>Y</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>E</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>Y</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>σ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

Also the third moment, $E[|G_i|^3]$, is finite. To proceed further, we state the Berry Esseen's theorem (see Theorem 6.4.1 in \cite{Athr}). 
\begin{prop}[Berry Esseen's Theorem]
Let $X_i,~1\leq i\leq n$, be an i.i.d. sequence of random variables with mean $\mu$, variance $\sigma^2 <\infty$ and $E[|X_1|^3] < \infty$. Let $S_n = \sum\limits_{i=1}^n X_i$. Then we have, for any $x \in \mathbb{R}$,

We pick $N_n$,  $E_{0n}$ and $\eta_n$ such that

	\item $0 < E_{0n} < N_n(E[Y])$.
	\item $\eta_n = o(\sqrt{n})$ and $\varepsilon_n - \varepsilon = o(\sqrt{n})$. 
\end{enumerate}
